intro: Cheiranthus frutescens, commonly known as the common wallflower, is an annual or biennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many flowering plants with four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and lobed leaves. Its flowers are usually bright yellow or orange, with four petals arranged in a cross shape, a characteristic of the Brassicaceae family. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats.
